text: Apple aroma. Off-white head that lingers. Restrained flavors with a lively and active finish. Not as good as the Trippel.

2016/11/30 - Pours a hazy amber brown colour with a thin off white head that quickly reduces and leaves moderate lacing. Aroma is sweet caramel, doughy yeast, red grapes, figs, plumbs and light molasses. Taste is toffee, dark fruits (figs, plumbs) and yeast with earthy and nutty notes. Mouthfeel is medium, with sharp carbonation and a dry, bittersweet finish. Not my favorite Allagash beer, but still very drinkable.
On draft at the brewery it is a cloudy red color with a white head. The aroma is malty and the taste is strong malty taste with hints of nuts

Bottle from Canals Bellmawr shared with Joe and Stash. Pours a hazy brown color with an off white medium head. Smell is dark malt, cherry, wood, belgian yeast and fresh baked bread. Flavor was prunes, fig, dark cherry, oak, and chocolate malt. Medium bodied. Tastes stronger than the alcohol percentage Enjoyable

Aroma - sweet malt, alcohol, cherry, and a slight wood.
Appearance - the body is a deep mahogany, the nucleation is constant and nice. The head is off-white and about 1/2". The head fades into a nice foam.
Taste - has nice semi-sweet dark malt. There is a little bit of chocolate, nut, some wine like dry sherry, and spice. The yeast isnt immediately obvious.
Palate - medium body, carbonation is average, finish is dry and slightly tannic and a very fine touch of bitters.

Bottle from Whole Foods Market in Redwood City, CA. Aroma is spice breads, burnt sugar. Taste is muddled...malty, some spiced raisin bread, yeasty, maybe wood. Not as smooth / fluid as I had hoped for, perhaps it really softens over time? Overall a little disappointing from the likes of Allagash.

Sample poured at Allagash. The pour is a darker amber color with a nice thick white head that slowly dissipates down to a thick bubbly collar with a good lacing. The aroma is very caramel forward. There is a light maltiness and Belgian spiciness to it, but the caramel lingers through out, which is why I think I like dubbels. Light alcohol on the back end. The flavor is definitely malty. There is a little twinge to let you know its not a traditional amber or English style ale, but its malty and caramel heavy like one. The mouth feel is a little thin on this with a brighter carbonation and a lingeringly caramel malty finish. This is a good surprise!

Bottle at Liquid Sunshine. Sweet, modest depth of sticky dark fruit on aroma. Sweet full body, nice American example of style.

Nice malty belgian, from the usa. Very bold caramel-like body with chocolate hints. BevMo SF.

Allagash knows what theyre doing, but we all know that. I havent had the dubbel because I feel itll be close to their tripel, which is a good beer, but doesnt blow me awaybut the Dubbel Reserve is cut from a different cloth. It pours a dark amber color and smells of fruit and sugar. It tastes of fruit and goes down very smoothly with a little bit of an edge to it that makes it unique. It says its aged in a cellar, and I wouldnt mind taking a trip to that cellar to thank it for its great work.

Flavor is similarly boring - some malt and slight tang of yeast, but overall watery with no really distinct flavors. Very smooth, and fairly clean finish, but just too weak/boring.

Was a gift from my cousin, Meghan, and her boyfriend Dan (whom couldnt make it). 750 mL purchased at the source, or so I was told. Read: "Batch# 113" on front of label. Aromas of banana bread, Belgian yeast, salted butter, molded tangerine, burnt plastic, sweat, and pistachios. Tastes the same with the addition of spent grain, unripe pineapple, aged hops, DME, and sweat. Bready with undertones of underripe tropical fruit, cotton, and yeast. The yeast character is transformative...it once had smelled like a boring (American take) Dubbel, but quickly had turned into something much more...was essenially akin to consuming stale pumpernickel doused in an expired store-bought punch blend...that sounded as if its distinctiveness had been horrendous and undrinkable, but, oddly enough, its unique, hearty, and palatable.  Im genuinely surprised I havent rated this until now.

I poured a 12oz bottle into an official Allagash tulip glass. It was bottled on 4/3/14 and cost $3.99 ($0.33 per ounce).

Appearance: Pretty chestnut red/mahogany hue. Pours to a two-finger, off white, foamy head which retains and laces fairly well.

Smell: Estery and fruity, though surprisingly mild. 

Taste: Allagash is one of my favorite American breweries when it comes to making Belgian-style beers. Ironically enough, Ive never actually had their Dubbel Ale out of the bottle until now (I had it on tap at the brewery and it was excellent). The palette is fruity, sweet and slightly smoky. It reminds me a homebrew dubbel I made, actually. Anyway, the taste is fine  I get a distinct cherry flavor, some plum or other stone fruit, and maybe some fig. Theres a slightly soapy character from the yeast, as well as some smoke or dry astringency on the finish. I was hoping for something more robust, but this is fine.

Drinkability: While Allagash Dubbel meets the criteria for a big beer at 7% ABV, it definitely doesnt drink like something big at all. The mouthfeel is calm, though far from flat. The texture and finish is smooth with no alcohol warmth whatsoever. Theres not much in the way of aftertaste, which is nice since theres no cloying or drying sensation  but some residual flavor would be nice.

Probably one of the best dubbels Ive had.

Medium body, thin and creamy texture, average carbonation, dry finish. A fine rendition of a Belgian Dubbel. You could pair this with many different kinds of food, I had it with liver and onions.

Allagash Dubbel is my introduction to the Maine brewerys Belgian-style ales. I can see what the hype is all about. This brew is a must for people who love hearty, malty ales and Belgian enthusiasts.

Just when I thought I had uploaded everything Ive had by Allagash, I find these notes.

Pours dark muddy brown with small tan fizz. Smells malty with strong fruity notes. Tastes malty and fruity with a touch of alcohol. Full-bodied with a slick texture and present mouth-carbonation, Allagash Dubbel Reserve finishes lightly dry like a red wine.

Light brown color with some red, cloudy, almost no head. Aroma is sweet and I pick up cherries and malt.  Taste is sweet but balanced.  Full mouth feel but with carbonation.  A nice beer on the sweeter side.

Pours a ruby/brown, with alight tan head.  Aroma is sweet, malty, with a light note of dried fruit.  Flavor of roasted malts, with caramel, dried fruit, and spices.  Finishes dry with a little spices lingering.

Bottle at le mondiale 2011. 
A perfect example of the style. 
An incredible balance between sweet bready, biscuity, caramel malts, and a good dose of lightly aromatic hops. Just the right amount of bitterness, and the malts are not overly sweet, just right. Incredible beer.

This is a good beer but honestly, I had higher expectations - but it is really good :-)  Now, mine was the Dubbel Ale not the Reserve, so maybe that makes a difference.  Out of the bottle it looked great.  Opaque, deep amber color; I like beers you cant see through!  The nose was very faint, I thought it would be totally aromatic but it wasnt... slightly bready.  The taste was good but not overwhelming with flavor.  The mouthfeel was perfect.  small bubbles, feels good rolling around on the tongue.  Im conflicted about this beer... I want to rate it higher but cant right now.  I need to try it again!

Tasted on 6/7/11 from a corked and caged 750mL bottle purchased at Binnys South Loop around a year ago.  Pours dar but clear amber with a thick , smooth off-white head that slowly recedes to a thin layer of even lace.  The nose is caramel malt, cola, hints of vanilla, cinnamon, spicy yeast, overall, pretty sweet.  The flavor is also fairly sweet with the caramel malt and cola up front, moving to the more baking spices with cinnamon, nutmeg, and vanilla, along with some spicy yeast.  The body is full with average carbonation and a long cola, and lightly bitter burnt caramel finish.

12 oz. bottle labeled Dubbel Ale.

Appearance: Pours a cloudy darkish amber color with a creamy light tan head that is has moderate duration and leaves plenty of lace.

Smell: Sweet with hints of raisins, figs, red wine and clove.

Taste: Has a richness and complexity rarely found outside the world of true Belgian dubbels. Plenty of fruity yeast and malt flavors tinted with cloves. 

Mouthfeel: Medium to full body with perfect moderate carbonation.

O - one of the best dubbels Ive ever had ... that wasnt brewed in Belgium; and better than some of those.  I bit more clove than Id prefer.

On tap @ Fountainheads. Pours a dark brown with a thick and lasting white head and lots and lots of lacing. The aroma is rather sweet with a little hint of raisins or currants. Flavor is surprisingly nutty with sweet malt flavors and a just a hint of fruitiness.
Copper brown with medium tan head.  Aroma malt, brown sugar, dried fruits.  Medium-full body.  Taste is mostly sweet malts, raisins, dough.  Sweet up front, finish not so much hoppy but dry.  Solid.
Labeled as Dubbel Ale. Pretty good example of the style. Pours dark brown with a big head. Yeasty, nutty, sweet.

Pours a nice reddish mahogany color with a huge beige head thats creamy and sticks around forever.  Thats how a dubbel should look!  Aroma of dates, raisin, sourdough bread, mushrooms, slight cheese, and brown sugar.  Great start so far, but unfortunately the flavor is too dry for my liking.  Theres some caramel and brown sugar, but its mostly about the mushroomy funky yeast, earthy bitter hops, and toasty qualities.  Some raisin comes through, but more at first than in the finish.  Medium bodied, highly carbonated, creamy and fluffy, with a moderate alcohol presence.  Love the appearance and aroma, but the flavor is just too dry.

750ml bottle.
Cloudy amber brown with a nice tan head.  Aromas of dates, caramel malt, and dry hot cocoa mix.  Flavors of raisins, clove, and caramel.  Decent.

Bottle. This beer pours a deep cloudy amber with a medium off white head.  The aromas are citrus, figs, apples.  The mouthfeel is sticky, sweet and dry with a medium body.  This was a very nice beer.  Cheers!

bottle; brown cloudy with moderate tan head; aroma-caramel, banana, spice and dried fruits, right in line with classic Dubbels; taste-watered-down and frankly disappointing. Mild sweetness, carbonation and bitterness. Good until you taste it. Probably need to age more
it smells like a skunk to me.  tastes really good though.  brown sugar, raisin, maple syrup. i enjoy drinking it - i just dont like smelling it.  pair with oatmeal raisin cookies!

(750ml bottle thanks to Dixonian) cloudy medium brown, creamy tan head and nice lacing. Nose of spent grain, raisin, and a bit of dry cocoa. Taste of unsweet raisin, cinnamon bread, alcohol, dry grain, creamy body. Easy to drink. Pretty nice dubbel for an American made.

Thuis poured a murky brown color with a beige head. The aroma contains some nutmeg, caramel,. toffee, and cherries. The flavor is excellent with some caramel, toffee, vanilla, and cherries. My only complaint, and its not much of one, is the body is a bit thin. Overall this is a nice beer

The beer pours a murky brown with a tan light head, not much retention or lacing.

The aroma is a little matly and some hops.

The taste is ok, nothing special, its pretty simple just a little malt not much else.

The feel is medium, ok drinkability.

Overall, a less than average dubbel.

Smell and taste are that of a traditional dubbel.  Might have been slightly more spicy and dry then others, but thats about the only distiction I could find.  Nice mouthfeel, well made.  Very good, solid beer, nothing mind blowing though.
355ml bottle from jsprime. pours light brown with an off white head. weird aroma of fallen leaves, maple, belgian yeast. flavour is spicey and complex. drinks like an fall dubbel. good.

750->trappist: Pours a brown, frothy, diminishing head that exhibits good lacing atop a murky, heavily particulate body.  Aroma of grain, yeast, and almonds and brown sugar to a minor extent.  The body is light, slightly sweet, and diminishes quickly.  There is a bitter and/or astringent component to this beer that I cant quite put my finger on, however, it is unique.

Little head with medium lacing over a hazy orange, yellow yeasty body.  Aroma is carmelized pine and sweetly fruity and spicy typical of the Abbey double style.  Not typical is the candy apple note.  But this is a fruitcake!  With bready aroma and all.  The taste is mildly bitter.  The palate is quite thin.  The overall is interestingly complex but only teasing and unsatisfying.

bought a 4 pack of this since I had not had any alla for awhile. This beer is a hazy light amber with a one finger head and some constant flowing bubbles up the side.  The aroma is yest esters that give a sense of green papaya and honey dew melon, with slight tart smell, definite light sweet smell. The taste start a bit sweet but moves into a solid malt base with a touch of bitterness to round it out. Palate is great with the sharp carbonation but a very round medium mouth feel.
Im concerned that this was twist off and their Wit and Tripel arent, perhaps an old bottle? It was pretty stale.
Im transferring ratings from another beer app to this one. My tasting notes wouldnt be accurate at this point since they werent captured at the time.

This beer pours a dark hazy orange with a thick tan head.  Dark fruit aromas came through easily.  The beer started lightly sweet and finished bitter.  The bitterness faded smoothly and there is a smooth silky mouthfeel.  The carbonation felt somewhat low, but this beer was a bit warm when drinking.

A: The pour is a bright and rich amber color with a creamy khaki colored head and some impressive lacing.

S: Quite hoppy, despite the oak aging, with a nice citrus character and quite a bit of pine, too. Theres a very strong oak aroma which provides some sweet vanilla notes. A slight booziness along with a lot of sweet caramel and toffee.

T: The sweetness of the caramel and toffee flavors are on display from the beginning here. The hops are more toward the back end providing a piney bitterness. Lots of oak and vanilla (bourbon?) with just a touch of alcohol warmth.

M: The body is on the full end of medium with a smooth carbonation.

D: This is the best of the four 30th Anniversary beers and just a fantastic one all around. I should probably pick up a few bottles of this.

UPDATED: JUL 27, 2011 Poured from a 12 ounce bottle into a Duvel tulip.

Appearance: Pours a hazy dark caramel color with a 1 finger bubbly off-white head which dissipates fairly quickly. Decent amount of fine-bubbled lacing.

Smell: Light Belgian yeast with clove and some winter spices I dont normally associate with the style. The aroma is not as strong as I would have preferred.

Taste: Typical dubbel flavor of Belgian yeast up front followed by dried fruits in the middle and ending with a bit of bitter hops at the finish. Aftertaste is dry and mildly bitter.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied with a good amount of carbonation.

Drinkability: Slightly above average drinkability. The alcohol is masked well, yet I wouldnt go back for another.

Overall: Pretty good dubbel overall. Not as good as I had hoped for considering the reputation of Allagash, but still a good beer nonetheless.

UPDATED: FEB 7, 2011 This was tasted in Cass, WV while skiing at Snowshoe.  Jonathan brought me the beer to taste. The beer poured with a nice frothy head and deep dark color.  The alcohol wes high but not detected.  I could not taste the chocolate or nuts.  A fun beer to drink in winter while it is snowing outside.  The finish was smooth with no aftertaste.  It  would  be great to have the time to watch this beverage mature to be port like.

From the 750 ml. corked bottle. Batch 95. It pours a cloudy amber-brown with a significant supply of foamy off-white head about three fingers deep. The aroma is noticeable from a distance with its fine wheat element, a slightly sweet maltiness, clove, and black pepper esthers.The body is nioce and full.  The taste is a nice balance of sweetness and bitterness with a smooth ending.  Really excellent.

Pour is a light brown color with a small off white, tan head. Nose is of sweet fruits. Taste is smooth with some light fruit notes, most noticeably apple and some spice notes in the finish along with a hoppy bitterness. Very light beer with a light carbonation on the tongue, overall very drinkable.

Batch #95.  Aroma of pear and tart apple.  Pours solid brown with generous white head.  Flavor is very fruity i realm of pear and apple again but freshened by a nice tart astringency.  Begins with nice light sweetness but finishes dry.  Very light bodied and drinkable.  I enjoyed this thoroughly although not as complex of some Belgians Ive had its a very well crafted beer.

750 ml. cork and cage bottle batch 94.  Shared in a limo on the way to Stone for my buddy Mikes 40th birthday.  Orange brown with creamy head.  Nose is smooth dark and spicy Belgian yeast.  Taste is roasty raisin and spice.  Lotsa sweet thickness and spice.  Too much for me.

12oz bottle labeled "Dubbel Ale", sweetness on the aroma, raisins, maybe brown sugar. Taste is nutty, some chocolate, but overall pretty watery and even at 7% they did a bad job of masking the alcohol. Not great.

Hazy amber pour off white/beige creamy head ..... aroma of sweet malts and grassy ..... taste of sweet malts, grassy sweet light fruity ... creamy with light chocolate and bready .... dry malty finish .... not bad sessionable
another great dubbel.  i couldnt pick out any fruit flavors... just bread and yeast and lots of it.  dominated by bread and caramel, almost like a Cow Tale without the cream filling.

Pours a deep walnut mahogany with a diminished head and mild lacing. The nose has notes of metal (copper), raisins, caramel, brown sugar and spices. The flavours follow suit accordingly, however, some smoky roasted tobacco bitters in the mid. The finish is almost cigar smoke, and the mouthfeel is full-bodied. This seems to be built upon much effervescence, and it does get better as it warms, but I guess Im not getting lost in its complexities. Not bad, but not as great as its hype... unfortunately.

Pours a dark reddish brown with a huge fluffy light brown head and decent lacing.  Smell is caramel and malty. Belgian with some dark fruits and alcohol coming through.  Tastes of alcohol up front gives way to caramel maltiness at the end and a nice hoppy dry aftertaste.
Still better than not drinking a Dubbel....Its a good example of the style, but kind of unremarkable. I drank this just after I was blown away by how great their Tripel Reserve was.

Bottle.  Pours clear tawny with an average, frothy beige head, medium retention with good lacing.  Aroma is heavy malt (caramel, nutty, toast, cookie), light hops (earthy, spicy), and average esters (dried fruit) with notes of prune, dates, and alcohol.  Flavor is heavy malt (caramel, nutty, toast, cookie), light hops (earthy, spicy), and average esters (dried fruit) with notes of prune, dates, and port.  Full body, medium warmth, carbonation, and creaminess with a sweet texture that dries out at the end.

On tap at the Taco Mac in Midtown Atlanta, GA. Pours light brown with a thin head that left tons of lacing. Im ashamed to say that I had a bite of my jalapeno laden quesadilla before my first smell and sip, so I cant place the aroma and flavor reliably. The palate was great; smooth and silky. This beer gave every indication of being great, so Ill be revisiting it when I have the occasion to give a proper review.

Sampled after the tour @ Allagash from a 750 ml bottle. A slightly hazy brown body with some red tint, covered by a beige head. Interesting spiced cake aroma with banana and citrus zest, maple and caramel, and plenty of yeast character. The flavor is moderately sweet, lightly fruity, with some caramel and nutty malt. The finish is mild to moderately bitter with some spicy hops, dry, and a bit light. The body is light and airy. this one definitely benefits from warming up a bit and releasing some of its ample carbonation. Let this sit awhile and it will not disappoint.

Brown, tan head.  A sour, fruity aroma - dark fruit.  Belgian twang with the taste of nuts and coffee - or perhaps chocolate.  Finish is more dark fruit.  Its really good, and since I love port, perhaps I should try putting a bottle back for next winter.

Bottle share with Andrew56. Fantastic brew. Great stuff making me look forward to the triple. Pours a hazy deep coppery murky brown. Sweet malts, nuts, slight sugaring  with a well balanced mouth. Low gas with nice fruit, low yeast. Subtle and tasty.
caramel with a medium white head.  malty with caramel and dark fruit flavors.  very good.

Pours a hazy brown with with a medium white head.  This beer has aromas of carmel, dark fruit and berries.  The flavor is malty and slightly sweet with light hops.  The beer is a bit creamy in the mouth with tiny bubbles at the end.  I was doing a taste test with Allagashs Tripel while rating this beer, and I think I prefer the Trippel.  This is a good beer that you can get many places, but it is not Allagashs best.

Allagash
Dubbel
Pours copper brown with a medium white head and good retention. Aroma is sweet smelling with raisins, roasted malts, and a mild funk similar to the Belgian funk. Flavor is toasty malts, with peaches and again with the funk. Super bubbly.
Pours a murky brown color, nose is raisins, molasses, quite a bit overcarbonated, tastes figgy, boozy, spicy, kind of a mess, but still drinkable.

Bottle. Pours a dark clear amber with a one-finger light head. Aroma is dark and sweet with toasted malts, maybe a hint of raisin, caramel, and nuts. Tastes strongly of caramel, but fades quickly to the toasty malts and finishes off clean and dry with some hops on the back end. Lots of carbonation, giving it a light and clean mouthfeel. Overall, a solid medium body brew.

batch 66 bottle thanks to boomer0813!!  i dont know how long I have been putting this off, but i am glad she brought it home for me.  poured a gorgeous ruby with a beige head.  aroma was malty, raisin, and black licorice.  flavor was malt, raisin, chocolate, and what seemed to be some wine characteristics.  body was light-medium with high carbonation and a rather dry finish.  excellent beer!!!  glad this is local to me and I might have to go pick up some more!!!

Pours clear ruby with lasting white head, aroma is some nuts, caramel, and burnt toast.  Very characteristic dubbel, with lively carbonation, relatively thin palate with nice burnt and caramel notes.  Nice brew.
I am a big fan of the reserve stocks from Allagash...wish they were available in Wisconsin.

hazy amber, creamy thick dense beige head, medium-full body, medium co2

aroma: bright and yeasty, sweet nutty malt, leafy hops, fruity alcohol.

taste: complex malt (nuts, chocolate, roast, grainy), hint of minerality, leafy herbal hops, high hop bitterness for style.

nicely complex malt character, but does not have the funky mineral notes that most dubbels have from the dark candy sugar. the hops seem fresh and american, rather than the typical stale european. overall, it comes across as a blend of belgian dubbel and american brown - i like it.
On tap at Allagash tasting at Stags Head.  Pours a hazy dark brown.  taste is earthy of toasted malt, molasses, dried fruiyts, nuts.  It finishes dry.  A decent dubbel

Appearance:  dark amber.  Aroma:  sweet and malty, rich with dark candied fruits.  Taste:  sweet and tangy, then bitter with the caramel fading.  Finish:  Dry, medium, suprisingly clean, slightly sweet.  Notes:  Had to bump this from a 2.5 to a 3 on the second go round.  Not nearly as good as Chimay Rouge, but a very acceptable Dubbel.

Label indicates Batch 91. Muddy amber/brown with a nice two-finger head and outstanding lace. Excellent blend of brown sugar, molasses, caramel malt aromas with a sense of floral hops in the background. Rich malt taste with a clean sugary sweetness and a touch of hops in the finish. Medium body, high carbonation, and a crisp clean finish. Nice.
12 ounce bottle purchased at Total Wine Pembroke Pines, FL for $2.99 Very good!

Bottle.  Pours a slightly hazy orange amber with a small white head.  Nose is sweet with some raisins, floral notes, spice, and caramel malts.  Medium body, less sweetness than suggested by the nose.  More dried fruits, spice, some yeast, lightly roasted caramel malt.  Finish is dry with more spice.

12 oz bottle.  Hazy amber hue with a small foamy head.  Aroma of ripe fruit, brewing sugar, yeast and caramel.  Medium, crisp body.  Taste is yeast, caramel malt, fruit and hints of earthy hops.  Medium, dry finish. Fine dubbel.
Bitter chocolate aroma, nutty taste. What a great beer! Comes only in pint size, the perfect size!

Poured a cloudy brown with an off white thin head but excellent lacing throughout.  Aromas were sweet - a little bitter chocolate, some candied sugar.  Dark malts came to the forefront in the flavor with some roasty and nut flavors.  Carbonation is solid and the flavor improves as it warms to room temperature.  Finish has an earthy linger - outstanding!!

Sample at the brewery. Pours a bronze brown with a white lasting head. Aroma is sweet, roasted and slightly fruity. The sweet and roasted aromas reminds me of mocha. I mostly get flavors of caramel and nuts. There is also some red fruits and yeast. Palate is quite thin and dry for the style but still fine. Considering I am not a dubbel fan, this is pretty good.

Bottle. Poured a medium hazy brown with a large off white frothy head that was mostly diminishing but had good lacing. The aroma was of roasted nutty malts, a sweet leathery yeast with hints of burnt coffee, molasses and a mild odor of dried fruit. It tasted lightly bitter in the beginning and finished with a malty-bitter flavor with notes of nuts and coffee with the flavor lasting an average amout of time. Mouthfeel was medium in body and creamy in texture with the carbonation being quite flat. Overall a tasty dubbel, but just an average brew.
Bottle from Cavie.  Hopefully past its prime.  Dark brown pour with a white head.  Aroma of dirt, yeast, and a little roasted.  Taste is old, very yeasty, dusty, a little nutty.

Bottle from Whole Foods. Batch 84. Raisin colored, cloudy maroon with foamy white head. Aroma of yeast, slight fruit and rot. Taste is dry like a peanut shell. Woody with huge dry flavors. Some off flavors; this tastes old. Horrible, horrible aftertaste. Like gnawing on a piece of rotting driftwood. This CANT be right.

Pours cloudy amber / bronze with nice tan long lasting head. Aroma is hops, sweet malty caramel. Taste is light hops, with malts dominating. Palate is medium to full body, good carbonation, creamy. Finish is sweet malty with some hops to balance this brew. A very nice well balance flavorful beer. Very enjoyable

Served from a 12 oz bottle from RateBracket winnings. The appearance is a hazy brown with some good bubbles and a micro white head. The flavors are aromas are dry yeast, dark malts, banana, nuts. Mouth is medium bodied with a nice carbonation. A solid brew.

poured into a Duvel tulip.

A-  Pored a mahogany color with a small head that disappeared quickly. Fair lacing.

S-  Malt and chocolate with dark fruits underneath.

T-  Thick malt flavor with a slightly sweet chocolate finish. A little lingering bitterness.

M -  Fills the mouth with a smooth mouthfeel and nice carbonation

D-  Not as complex as I expected. Not a bad drinker.

Dark amber/cider color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of malt, yeast, dark fruit, toffee, & spice; Flavor of slight sweet malt, yeast, caramel, dark fruit, raisons, and spice; Fairly well balanced; An average dubbel ale for me.

Batch #79 750ml caged and corked bottle.

Appearance: Iced tea / bronze body with off white 2 finger foam head. This one will really foam up without an experienced gentle pour. Lots of head retention and gobs...thats right I said gobs of lacing.

Smell: Lots of sweet fruity notes along with a bready malt and clove note. The belgian yeast dominates the nose though.

Taste: Loving the flavors here...bready malt, dark fruits, beligan yeast, clove, etc. Really works well and is extremely refreshing.

Mouthfeel: closer to medium than light bodied with a nice creamy quality found in the crown.

Drinkability: I could knock a couple 22ozs back in a night.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-22-2009

A longtime favorite, though this is my first time to rate this. This 12 oz bottle is relatively young - I bought it in December 2009 - but, even so, its nose is richly yeasty. This hints at the smoothness of the texture to come, which is one of the beers finer characteristics. Flavors typical of a Belgian dubbel - stone fruit, yeast, and a touch of funk - predominate in this very nice American incarnation of a classic old world style.

Dubbel Reserve Belgian Style Ale Batch # 50--2005 25.4 oz. Bottle.  7.00% ABV.  15 IBUs?  (4.25 / 5.0)  Belgian Ale--Amber Dubbel.  2 @ $7.59 Each.  Fizzy mild lace light beige head.  Clear dark mahogany red color.  Mellow Belgian plum fruit ester front.  Mild sweet chocolate black cherry toffee dark Belgian candy malty body.  Smooth mild hop sherry port end.  Rich tight mellowing sediment at end.  Nice.  Sampled 12/28/2008.

Pours light brown and slightly cloudy.  I wish it was a bit darker, but oh well.  This smells spicy and refreshing, almost like it has wheat in it.  Flavor is similar with a bit more sugar to it.  Its definitely lacking the dark fruit, dates and molasses or burnt toast appeal that many good doubles have.  Overall though, its pretty nice.

Bottle. Appearance is nut brown with a very thin layer of milky head. Aroma is cocoa, molasses and caramel. Flavor begins with an assertive caramel and toasted malt sweetness followed by raisins, burnt sugar, coffee, pecans and roast malt. Mouthfeel is slightly creamy with low-to-medium carbonation. It finishes toasty and woody with a mild chocolate aftertaste. Overall flavor is nutty and malty with lots of dark sugar sweetness.
Bomber. Pours with a big foamy head. Nice malty base with a general apple/orange base flavor. Also has the characteristic Allagash yeast taste.

A- hazy translucent medium brown body. Pours with relatively thin off-white head that quickly fades to a nice collar. Little lacing is left behind in the glass.

S- Deep, rich, roasted malt smell. Hints of Belgian sugars.

T- Initial taste is of bready and roasted malt-somewhat bitter. Finish is yeasty and sugary. Quite sweet. This is a brew that activates every taste bud on your tongue. Pretty interesting and complex.

P-Medium carbonation and light weight body. Goes down fairly smooth.

O- This is a pretty good brew and the 7% ABV is pretty well hidden. One that I will probably venture to have again.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 07-19-2007 18:13:46

Caramel and dried fruit on the nose. Pours an amber brown color with a white soapy head.  Has a spicey dubbel taste.  Sweet and malty with a subtle bitterness.  Notes of bubblegum.  A less fruity, drier version of this classic style.  Never dissapointed with Allagash.

Deep dark amber with fair head. Aroma is a mixed bag of really nice sweetness and a faint hint of trashcan. Flavor is surprisingly mild overall, but the funky flavor breaks through here and there (not my thing). Feels a bit too fizzy, too.

Pours dark amber with a thick foamy tan head.  In the nose you get abbey yeast, spice, died fruit, and sweet malts.  Those flavors most common to this style are all present as well as a roasted character balanced with lots of hops which give the beer a slightly bitter finish.
dark brown color with small head. Aroma and flavor are very malty, but mild.

Pours an amber color with a thin beige head that disapates quickly. Decent amount of lacing on the glass. Aroma of dried fruit and light chocolate along with faint of hops. Taste of fruit, malt, nuts and faint chocolate - nice and medium-bodied and smooth.The finish is lightly spiced with a malty aftertaste that lingers perfectly.  I really enjoyed this one.
Cloudy light brown color.  Aroma is made up of malts, apples, and some smoke.  Flavor is a little bitter consisting of sweeter malts and some earthiness.  Finish to me is a smoked ending.

Pours dark plum with a nice off white head that lingers around through out.  Yeasty aroma with a little malt.  Slight bitter and spritzy taste.  somewhat dry hop lingering finish.  Decent American style Belgian dubbel.

Mellow dubbel that is predominantly yeasty and bready, but slightly fruity as well--maybe cherries (but not sour).  Good carbonation.  Very easy to drink.  Color is a hue of red.  Really did enjoy this beer.
Bottle. Pours a light plum color with a small white head. Nose is far fruits and a doughy malt note. Palate is fizzy and light. Flavor is doughy with light plum notes.
Ruby red with a thin white head on it.  Has a strong tangy, earthy, rotten fruit flavor that turns me off a bit. A decent beer but doesnt stand up to many other Dubbels out there.

Amber pour with foamy tan head. Aroma is light brown sugar, and bread. Flavor is sweet malty start with a metallic finish. Carbonation and body are good. Third time Ive had this beer first time Ive tasted the metallic. Liked everything about it except the finish.
Pours a dark brownish red, hazy and cloudy. The aroma is fruity and malty. Is incredibly smooth with a nice long aftertaste .

28th October 2008. Hazy brown beer with a thick creamy head. A little sourness rapidly followed by a dry spicyness which the creamy head offsets well. A little sour malt in the finish which is a bit too dry. Not bad but something is missing.

POurs a dark amber with a large honey hued head, nice lacing.  Aroma was of hops, some citrus and caramel.  First sip is sweet which tasted faintly of raisins and oranges.   Finishes dry with a nice taste of hops and a bit of alcohol heat.
Bottle. Dark and opaque amber pour with a thin head. Aroma consists of caramel, candi sugar and dark fruits. Tastes very sweet, slightly sour, accompanied by a slightly bitter finish.

Batch 58. Poured into an Allagash goblet. Appearance is brown with a rich, creamy head. Smell is of malt and dark fruits. This beer tastes like it smells, with a slight hop bitterness but mainly raisins and plums. The beer was very carbonated. This is what I am looking for in a Belgian Dubbel.

A: Poured with a very spare head that quickly diminished to a ring on top of the beer. Body is dark brown and hazy.

S: Pretty good aroma of some roastiness, clove, and some fruit as well.

T: Slightly fruity, with hints of dark chocolate. Seems like there may be cloves in there as well. Finishes a bit dry, but otherwise a pretty smooth-drinking beer.

M: Medium-bodied, creamy, with lively carbonation.

D: A pretty easy-drinking dubbel. A very solid representation of the style, and lives up to the high Allagash standards.

Enjoyed this on a pristine lake setting with one of the brewers from Troue Du Diable, it was a trade for sampling some of his brews over the course of a weekend. Chin Chin to such an enjoyable industry, where friends are never hard to find.
Hazy amber, with a modest head.  Malty, sour aroma.  Light and tart, with a real sour finish.
user_location: Peoples Republic of Athens, Ohio, USA

text:
12oz Bottle. Rated blind. Sixth out of a set of 12 Abbey Dubbels. Aroma presents a soft, 

supple lightly sweet toffee, hazlenut, and a golden raisin sugar. Mature 

and warm. Very nice. Pours a cloudy darkened amber with a super-sticky 

cream head. Flavor is sharper, more grating and less refined. A harsh, 

slightly bitter grain alcohol and hop acid comes first, followed by a 

coarse, gritty sugar. The flavor is a bit of a let down after such a 

nice aroma. A nip thin, with rising caramelization, Munich-like malt 

complexity and amber fruits in the backend. This smoothes out 

considerably as it opens up and breathes, with a encompassing spicy 

yeast profile to tie the beer together in the end.
GUESS: Westmalle or Binchoise

Batch 84 purchased at Total Wine in Tampa.  Presents as a reddish-brown with minimal tan head.  Nose of sweet fruit.  Nose translates to the taste of figs, apples and plums combined with some sweet malt.  This Abbey Dubbel is somewhat understated.  I suspect maturation will greatly improve the quality of this selection

Bottle (in NZ). Quite light for a Dubbel - but it isnt losing anything for it. Plenty of spice on the palate, working well with the caramal and stoned fruit flavours. The kind of Dubbel you could drink a lot of.
Smooth, warm and light. Slightly hoppy. Very nice bitterness with no lingering aftertaste.
Dark red-brown with a creamy but thin lasting beige cover.  Aroma of dried dark fruits, light alc.  Taste is caramel, fruity, a bit dry, some spicy esters, prune, raisins, apples.

750-ml bottle of batch #77 Marcellos Lafayette, LA - Aroma: sweet, bread, caramel (malt), earthy, fruity esters of dried fruit, lemon, tangy, nuts (yeast); Appearance: hazy, reddish-brown color, light-tan head, lots of laces; Flavor: sweet, salty, bread, chocolate (malt), bitter, (hop), raisin, sour (yeast), alcohol; Mouthfeel: medium bodied, slick texture, lively-high carbonation, long bitter finish; Overall: malt, yeast, and alcohol balanced, with tones of sweet and sour, raisin, and prunes, which finishes tangy, long bitter-chocolate and dry.

Batch #82. Mighty fine Dubbel! Pours a cloudy dark brown into a Piraat Chalice. Thick tan head sticks around. Aroma is raisins and must. Flavor is raisins, figs, dried prunes and a little cola. Finishes clean.

12oz bottle from a recent trade....pours a medium semi-transparent caramel brown with a thin to medium frothy white head... aroma had more brown sugar and maple notes than anything else.  slight chocolate and a very subtle roast to it even.... flavors of dark fruit and less complexity than the aroma.  caramel malts and a semi-effervescent carbonation. somewhat of a thin body.
Bottle. 25.4 oz. Pours deep amber with a thick, frothy tan head. Aroma of barley, toasted malts, and raisins. Well-rounded body and mouthfeel. Quick, nice finish. Good dubbel.

UPDATED: SEP 2, 2010 Pours with a nice compact head. Spicy, pumpkin pie aroma. Sweet and malty with very slight sour finish. Tastes a bit like an old ale along the lines of Great Divides Hibernation.
Solid dubbel here. Had on tap at Blind Tiger. Poured a hazy, dark amber with a medium head. Highly malty aroma with some wild, yeasty odors. Flavor of sweet malts and some bread. Clean, crisp finish.

UPDATED: AUG 25, 2010 From Norms Beer And Wine:

Aroma: Light caramel nose.  Nice dark color.  Flavor is mildly sweet.

Bottle. Poured a rich mahogany with a thin off white head. Nose had some candied sugar and Belgian yeast. Nicely carbonated and easy drinking. Has a nice malt yeast backbone but lacks some depth. I had this right After An allagash triple and found the dubbel to be less complex.  Definitely improves as it warms and reminds me a bit of RR salvation.

Bottle.  Poured a dark auburn-brown with a nice, medium sized off white head.  Aroma of cocoa, nuts, caramel, fruit and bread.  A nice blend.  Flavor was not mind blowing, but it had some complexity and was very drinkable.  Palate was a negative, a bit thin and harsh from the carbonation.  After taste is also just ok.  Great aroma, ok flavor, crappy palate.

(Bottle poured into trappist glass).  Poured very dark brown with very small head, and you could smell the complexity of the malts... with a hint of cocoa(?)  Flavor retained the malty sweetness, but it was not overpowering.  Finished with a bitter aftertaste that provided a nice bite at the end.
From a bottle poured brown with a small head.  Nice malty sweet flavor with a quick spicy finish.

12oz bottle from? a year or so ago poured at 55F.  Pours a dull unclear brown with a medium densely packed beige sudsy foamy froth 3.5.  Aroma is pleasant of oxidized malt, dusty light chocolate, nutty, doughy, very light fruit, light but rich raisins, nice mix of yeast and alcohol, my favorite type of aroma likened to Great Divide Hibernation 7.5.  Flavor is sweeter and more metallic, some bright fruits and citrus/lemon overpower the chocolate and nuttiness underneath, light bitterness towards the finish.  Medium/light bodied, very actively lively fizzy carbonation, too much, a bit chalky but seemingly very thin.  Eh... doesnt live up to the aroma.

deep cloudy orange-brown with yellowish fizzy head.
spicy and tart yeast aroma with sourdough and lemon.
dry wood and even a bit astringent, flavor is mostly a nice fruity yeast, along with some cinammon, cardamom, bitter orange peel, and a hint of pine in the finish.
this is great -- refreshing and well-balanced, though not as belgian-y as youd think: much drier and mellower. maybe slightly on the thin side.

Bottle.  Dark brown pour, with super long-lasting tan head.  I poured this awhile ago and the head still lasts.  Great looking.  Deep scent...sweet, dark fruits.  Taste is good....not as spicy as I would have liked, but a nice complex flavor.  Very delicious...better than the Ommegang Abbey Ale, I think. (tried to think of a comparable beer)

This dubbel had a nice brown color with a dirty-white head floating on top. A musty smell at first and a pleasant taste with chocolate and estery flavors. I liked this beer and it was easy to drink. Very nice dubbel and at $6 a bottle a pretty good deal.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-12-2007 17:08:26
Im not entirely sure why we disliked this beer.  Perhaps were not into beers that are malted sweet.  I want to try it again,m to make sure my opinion wasnt skewed by chriss hate of sweeter beers.

Tasted at brewery.  Pours golden brown, big creamy head.  Aroma is slightly syrupy, a combination of sugar and hop resin.  Very drinkable, mostly because the balance is spectacular.  You get some roast flavors and theres the perfect amount of bitterness to keep it dry.  Yay beer!
Jenn likes this one.  It is reminiscent of the fall and winter seasonal brews, with a malty flavor and little aftertaste.

Batch 82 - 750mL bottle into an abbey glass.  The beer pours deep brown and red with a khaki head that shrinks a bit with time.  The aroma is noticeably sour at first which gives way to roasted malt and a dash of wood.  The flavor is sour at the front of the mouth and rolls across into a dark and dry combination of malt, slightly smoked meats, and a hint of nutty wood and tobacco.  Medium body and high carbonation typical of Belgian styles.  Overall, the flavor was a bit too earthy and meaty for my full enjoyment.

Dark browns and faded blacks fill out the curves of my glass while a gentle head of khaki mousse fades into a shy ringlet. A thin blanket of khaki foam remains, and as I swirl my glass, a rush of mouth-watering aromas make a mad dash for my olfactory indulgence. Sweet, spiced, plump, and a touch fruity. Maple and toffee mingle with brown spices, wood, and vanilla root. Her nose exudes supple warmth, a worthy compliment to succulent cooked red apples, pears, and prunes sprinkled with a none-too-shy helping of cinnamon fresh from the stick. Toasted sugars crunch, blending into wood, spice, and warmth. Smitten, I raise my chalice of swirling dark delights to eager lips which are met by a softly effervescent mouthfeel which belies a full body of chewy dark breads, prunes, and dark raisins. Despite her dark appearance, her palate shines with crunchy sugars atop toasted raisin bread which leads into a symphony of wood. Her finish is long, her warmth slowly but surely invading my chest and the back of my throat. If humans could purr in soulful satisfaction, my chest would be rumbling right now. Medium weight and a full palate keep my senses busy. As we spend more time together, a subtle dryness refreshes just in time for the next juicy quaff. A perfect merry-go-round of crunchy sweet, cooked fruits, dark fruits, toast, spice, and wood. Seeing as my Allagash Dubbel came in a magnificently corked 750ml bottle, I have another full glass to sit back and savor. Its a hard job, but somebody has to do it.


Allagash never lets me down, and their Dubbel is no exception. If you are looking for a fine craft example of the traditional Belgian dubbel style, then look no further.
Ruby red with a vanishing head at pour. Nutty at first taste. The body seems a little too thick, at times. Smooth, though. Dark malt character at the finish. Incredibly drinkable. A very solid beer.

750ml. bottle from City Market Vermont.The color is ruby with a nice beige head.The taste is of lots of malt and some yeast and an added sweetness of caramel. Also in the taste and aroma is the sensation of grapes, this is not overpowering but it gives it a nice finish.

Thick, murky rose-brown color: amazing color. Head disappears almost instantly; better head would have improved it. Cherry liqueur in the nose, crystalline candi sugars. Sweet with a dark, dried-date aroma. Flavor is darkly, sugary sweet (corn sugar), dark grape and wine and sour cherry notes. Dark malt, a little more darkly sour as it warms; saccharine toward the end. Creamy and not that fizzy on the tongue. Well-balanced and easy to drink considering its 7% abv.

Pours a cloudy brown, maybe reddish brown. with a half inch of dense tan foam. Aroma is a bit fruitier than I expected. Flavor is a bit biting, maybe even a bit tinny/piney, which overpowers the sugary maltiness I was expecting. Not bad, but Ive come to expect better from Allagash.

Bottle from batch 71.  Pours a large, fluffy, quivering, clingy, light tan head.  Clear, ruby body with abundant, dancing carbonation bubbles.  Looks great!  Aroma is of fruity esters, light alcohol, caramel malt, some miscellaneous dark fruit and dark cherry.  The flavor adds some spicy phenols, light raisin, some old dust, and a little rum.  No discernible hop presence.  Medium bodied, with prickly, lively carbonation.  Palate is a bit sticky...perhaps the attenuation was a little low?  Maybe a bit more candi sugar would be in order?  Light, warming alcohol.  Overall very good - would be great if the body were a little lighter/thinner.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2015 Corked and caged, batch 71.  Nice overspilling nose, gentle caramel and rich earthy brown malt, sweetness with dusty hops and a touch of smoke/roast.  Ruby-brown, not really translucent, with a lovely creamy, spoonable tan head, laces like a mfer but a little sudsy.  Sweet start gives way to rich maltiness; good complexity, with pittier fruits coming through, a touch of dry wood and smoke in the back.  Overall, about as balanced as a malt-forward beer can be.  Medium body dries out toward the end, a touch of brown sugar.  No alcohol until the light warming of my outer cheeks.  Classy, mellow rendition, the type I wish flew from a font in my backyard and allowed daily imbibing. [2009.07.18: 3.7]A smaller bottle, this time 12 oz with a cap. Short of gushing, but the room fills with enormous overripe fruit nonetheless, principally cherry and red berry, with some expected dark toffee and mineral character, brown sugar.  A little more booze showing than Id like, and perhaps a shade less maltiness (though its still pretty thick with maltiness), but overall scores high in all areas, really bold and fruity / classic dubbel while maintaining a more personal eccentricity with light wood and faint smoke.  Fresh and still superb. [2015.06.10: 4.0]

Dark pour, offwhite head.  sampled at the Brewery.  Aromas of banana, yeast, caramel, some pepper and some dark fruit.  Flavor is yeasty with banana and clove and some woodiness.  medium mouthfeel, finish is a bit boozey
Draft at The Bier Garden.  Pours a fading off-white head with a dark amber body.  Smells of yeast, banana, barnyard, and clove.  Flavor is yeast, banana, clove, and zest.  Finish has a nice dryness.

Draft from a tulip. Appearance: Amber with an off-white head and nice lacing. Aroma: The only thing I can pick up is bubblegum on the nose. Flavor: Yeast, nuts, and a hint of chocolate. Palate: Medium body with a smooth texture.

Pours out a translucent, ruby-hued brown with a puffy, mostly lasting tan head. The nose is of raisin, fig, chocolate, grahm cracker and spicy yeast. The flavour is similar, though heavier on the nutty character, as well as the spicy notes from the yeast, which linger nicely in the very dry finish. It is complemented by the prickly mouthfeel and airy body. Allagash has never failed me.
Dark brown pour with tan head.  Caramel in aroma with some spices.  Yeasty in flavor with some hints of chocolate.  Smooth finish.

Clear burnt umber with a large tan lace maker of a head.  Aroma of spice, Belgian yeast, brown sugar and grains, all pretty faint though.  Taste of brown sugar, mild fruit and burnt malts.  Body seems a bit thin.  Smooth and uninspiring, a let down since I do like the style.

Bottle, with Alaskanwarren. Thanks for sharing this one Brian! Ruddy brown, tan head. Woody toasted caramel aroma, very nice peppery esters, oyster brine. Warm brown bread flavor with pinch of cocoa powder. Perfectly dry and delicate finish. A dubbel that feels like it comes from a deep understanding and appreciation of the real Belgian roots. Very, very nice.
12oz screwtop. Labeled as Dubbel Ale. Pretty good example of the style. Pours dark brown with a big head. Yeasty, nutty, sweet.

12 ounce bottle in Westmalle glass.  Muddy dark brown with ring and a little lace.  Toasted caramel brown sugar aroma with dark fruit yeast and a little alcohol.  Toasted brown sugar with fruit and maple syrup with mild tang and medium spicy finishing bitterness.  Medium body and decent mouthfeel.  One of my least favorite styles.  And there are better ones.  But still decent enough.  Maybe I imagine it, but I think this is probably better out of a 750.
Enjoyable, some fruity notes, mostly non-citrus.  Nothing terribly special but nice for something that is very available.

dk brown with big rocky head. s - strong sweet malt, pepper and farmy. t - slightly dilute. apple. toffee. p -soft but seltzery

batch #80

pours a deep brown with small head. aroma is yeast/bread, roasted malts, apple peel, nuts, and sweetness. drinks smooth with malty roasted nuts and sweetness. yeast is very present but not oppressing.
Not bad Allagash.  Much better than you white I tried.  I did enjoy this, well done.  Another example of why I went to beerfest.

Batch # 68. Mice pop while opening. Brown pour with light tan head. Head is thick and frothy. Sweet and yeasty aroma. Dry crisp taste- mild sweetness and noticeable yeast flavor. Alcohol is barely noticeable.

Poured a clear, dark as ever red until I dumped the yeast in. Now its a cloudy dark nut brown with a pretty frothy beige head. Aroma is all Belgian white...clove, yeast, and a touch of banana. Mouth feel is thin and flavor is watery, then dry. Finish is slightly nutty, but is uncomfortably dry.

12 oz bottle poured into a goblet. Hazy russet brown with a modest off-white head that doesnt leave much lacing. Aroma is pretty faint but I get notes of dark breads, stone fruit, and clove. Flavor is more robust than the aroma but its still not as deep or complex as most authentic Belgian dubbels. Figs, burnt toast, raisins, pepper, clove. Mouthfeel is a touch watery with somewhat rough carbonation. Lacking in aroma, flavor, finesse, and fullness.

Batch 62 - I think this is a relatively aged bottle even though I bought only a few months ago.  750mL bottle from Holiday Wine Cellar (Escondido, CA).  Pours a deep mahogany color with one finger of off-white head.  Nice rich aroma, primarily of malty caramel but also some brown sugar and dark fruit.  Taste is malty and pleasantly sweet with dark fruit present...and definitely some dark chocolate which was a little surprising.  Light mouthfeel for the style.  Some more of that dark chocolate in the finish.  Rating #21.

Bottle.  Pours a mahogany body with a big off white head.  Chewy with hints of caramel malt, spices, and some unrefined sugar.  Dusty apple caramel notes and an almost spiced rum sweetness.  Great stuff.

I have never had a bad bottle. For a flagship this one is great. Very good belgian flavors of spice and candy. Some fruit and raisins and berries blend well with the creamy body from the caramel and molasses. Faint burnt character that lends to the bitterness with the hops. Very good.

Bottle. Pretty beer I think - but I see the opinions on that are quite mixed. Id had three of the four-pack before rating this last one. The first taste was everything I look for in a Belgian - sweet, fizzy, malty, crisp, tart. But every taste thereafter was muted, missing something. Or maybe I just prefer the tripel. I try to tell myself not every beer has to hit me over the head with flavor, but maybe I dont believe me.

Courtesy of SHIG. Pours dirty brown with thin tan head. The modest aroma is sweet with brown sugar, prunes, figs and a bit of pepper. The taste is much the same with brown sugar sweetness, prunes, figs, muted cherries, pepper, black grapes and then more prunes for good measure. Underneath those notes is a thin layer of yeasty spices.

Thanks SHIG for the share.  Pours hazy brown with a nose of caramel, yeast, chocolate, cherries, some sugar, and some dark fruit.  Flavor is yeast, chocolate, malt, and dark fruit.  Fizzy and lots of yeast character in the medium-bodied dubbel.  It really makes me wonder what the regular dubbel is like, if this one is the reserve.  Hmmmmm...

Bottle, courtesy SHIG. Turd water brown pour, with gray highlights and a very frothy head, and thick lacing. Spicy nose, dark fruits, cotton candy, slight caramel. Flavor is sharp fruit with dry malts, caramel and some cocoa. Smooth, full-bodied, but kinda one-dimensional.
Bottle: Poured a orange hazy brown with white head. Aroma is fruit with sweet malts. Taste is sweet fruit with a slight booze finish. Not an overwhelming dubbel in my book.

courtesy of sigh
batch 78.
Pours murky dark brown with white head.
Aroma is fruity some licorice and roasted malts.
Taste is yeasty, dark fruits (cherry) malty and candi sugar and some other spices that add a nice fresh mouthfeel.
poured a dark amber, brown with a nicely sized white head. aroma of small belgian spices and oaky malt. Taste matches, well balanced.

Comes out of the tap an opaque light chocolaty brown with a fairly thick, pale tan head. Rich, smoky, malty aroma has a yeasty undertone, and invites a taste. Flavor is malty with hints of cinnamon, cloves, yeast and caramel - very toothsome. Texture is very smooth and leaves behind a nice tingle.

Poured from a 750ml, batch 71. Dark brown pour with a big tan head. Aroma of raisins, caramel, dark sugar, mollasses, some fruit. Flavor is dark fruit and belgian spices. Some chocolate, and plums. Nice thick mouthfeel with lingering finish. Pretty good dubbel.

Poured from a 750ml caged and corked bottle (Batch #68) and served in a tulip.  This dubbel poured a dirty, caramel/copper brown with a short-lived head of tan foam that settled into a lasting ring.  Decent lacing.  The aroma included dark candi sugar, raisins, caramel, along with a faint note of chocolate.  The flavor contained dark fruit skins, candi sugar, light chocolate, and also a bit of alcohol in the finish.  Everything about the flavor seems to be muted.  Just not as vibrant as I was hoping for.  The mouthfeel was medium-bodied with a moderate amount of crisp carbonation.  Definately not a bad representation of the style, but not my favorite.

Enjoyed from a 750ml bottle.  Initial appearance is characteristically dark, with an off-white head, nicely bolstered from a generous level of carbonation.  The flavor is full on the palate; one of dark fruits, burnt raisons, and a slight note of alcohol on the back end.  An extremely well-crafted and enjoyable example of a classic style.

Pours a deep brown color with a small tan head. Nice tan lacing lasts throughout. Heavily carbonated. Aroma is of malt, caramel, grass, sugar, and yeast. The beer is way too malty for a dubbel. Taste is of heavy malt, caramel, spice, yeast, grass, and raisins. Alcohol presence is very noticeable. Lingering grassy taste. Far too malty, and too much earthiness in the taste. Not very good in my opinion.
Deep, dark amber.  small bubbles, small head with staying power. bubbly mouthfeel,  small amount of spice, dry finish.  Good, but not outstanding.

Very dark deep copper brown, cloudy.  Aroma sweet, slightly spiced.  Sweet malty flavor, slightly nutty, candy sugar (but only a little).  Dark fruit.  I was surprised at how dry this one is.  Finishes very dry, and flavors are all quite light.  Very carbonated mouthfeel.  Because of the dryness to me it almost has a salty finish, kind of bland.  Good, not great.

Attractive beer, reddish brown, creamy tan head.  The aroma started out as wheat, cloves, orther malts, but as it warmed evinced more candy sugar, and definitely more alcohol.  The flavor was typical of the style, a mix of sweet malts, molasses, ceral grains.  The finish had a decent hop signature.  Not bad overall.

On Draught at Plan B, dark amber with a good sized head, went great with a burger and fries, nicely malty and not too strong. subtle spices, a lot less than Allagash white but still there, a very nice beer.
Pours a very nice dark amber/brown color with a smooth wonderful white forming head.  Great taste of malts and dry hops.  Very good overall brew.  Great job Allagash.
12 oz. Not much of a flavor.  Okay, but better in the larger corked bottle as shown.

Pours a maple brown with little head. Flavor is of prunes, chocolate, and a little molasses way in the back. Not very sweet at all. The unsweetened chocolate flavor is a little too dominant over the others in my opinion. Didnt tickle my fancy, nevertheless good overall.

750 ml corked and caged bottle poured a hazy copper brown with a small lasting amber head. Aromas of carmel, raisin, spice and a hint of brown sugar. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of carmel, spice and light fruittiness with a smooth malty finish.

Nos yeux observent une bière de couleur rubis trouble et un col de mousse fauve qui simpose du début jusquà la fin de la dégustation. Au nez on découvre des arômes de vieille pipe à fumé le tabac, de grain fumé, de raisin , de chocolat et de réglisse, le tout sous un fond dalcool. En bouche le corps est rond avec une effervescence faible-moyenne. On goûte des saveurs de grain fumé, de caramel fonçé, de raisin et de fleurs. La finale présente des notes de torréfaction ainsi quune bonne amertume. Complexe et excellent

Pours a deep amber color with a small, tightly packed head retreats to a ring.  Sweet toasty malt, apples, yeast and spice in the aroma.  Flavor is big on caramel and ripe fruit.  A bit of spicy hop on the finish.  Light and dry on the palate.  Not bad at all!
Bottle. Pours dark brown with thick brown head. Aroma is bready with some apples and cinnamon. Flavor is fruity with some coffee notes. Light and bubbly on the palate. Very nice.

75cl bottle.   My first Allagash beer, and a decent dubbel.   Good looking beer: a slightly hazy brown body with some red tint, covered by a big beige head.   Interesting spiced cake aroma with banana and citrus zest, maple and caramel, and plenty of yeast character.   The flavor is moderately sweet, lightly fruity, with some caramel and nutty malt.   The finish is mild to moderately bitter with some spicy hops, dry, and a bit light.   The body is light and airy.   this one definitely benefits from warming up a bit and releasing some of its ample carbonation.   Mixing the yeast in adds some more complex, nutty, woody flavors.   A bit subtle, but I really warmed up to this by the end.   Dubbel is a style that I don*t drink too often, but it*s what started me on Belgians in the beginning, and its always nice to find a new, solid example of the style.

375ml bottle, batch 32. Pours a dark brownish-amber color with a thin beige head that disapates quickly. Patchy lacing on the glass. Dried fruit and light chocolate in the nose, with a touch of hops. Medium-bodied and smooth with a faint nutty character, and flavors of fruit, chocolate and malt. The finish is lightly spiced with a malty aftertaste that lingers awhile. An above average dubbel that I would recomend.
Ruddy brown pour with very thin tan head. Nose is dried dark fruits, caramel and some yeast influence. Flavor is quite the same but less full. Slight spice finish.
Dark amber, malty, dark fruits, brown sugar, molasses, caramel, little nutty, little spice, dry finish.
Appearance: Murky ruby brown, small head. Aroma: Smoke and malt, some tiny amount of hops detected too. Flavour: Bitter with malt, peppers and dark fruit. Quite a dry finish

25 oz. bottle .Batch 70. Pours a thick, lasting, tan head of good duration, some minimal lacing....over a dark coppery brown body....nose of malts in multiple layers with some hop spice, bit of cherry, not sweet.... taste is initially rather light, then sweet malts, with some further fruits, raisin and cherry, finishes with lingering hop bitterness....mouth feel is a little lighter than expected. 11/26/2008
Brown pour.  Small tan head.  Aroma is chocolate, cherries, some toffee and yeast.  Flavor is sweetish, honey, yeast and some sweet malt.  Nice beer from USA.

Poured into Chimay chalice. Pours a dark, cloudy amber with a small but long-lasting head. Aroma is milk chocolate, dark fruits (black cherries), yeast. Initial taste is a bit watery and bland but then turns more refined. Lots of malt and brown sugar and good balancing hops. Yeast is not too prevalent unlike abbey dubbels. Aftertaste is dry and long-lasting but pleasant. Lacing is most excellent.

Bomber.  Pours a crimson brown with a large creamy head.  Aroma of soft malt, caramel and dark fruits.  Flavor is soft and well blended, and there is a surprisingly nice touch of hops in there for complexity.  As is Allagashs trademark style, this brew is subtle, soft, and tremendously drinkable.  It is clearly the blend of a true brewmaster.

Bottle.  Pours a nice light brown color with off-white, frothy head.  Aromas of roasted malt, molasses, and some sweetness.  Palate is fantastic with a creamy start and very smooth finish.  Taste is nicely balances with malts, sweets, and subtle hops.  I will purchase this beer again.

Pours a three-finger light tan head, fades slowly, but leaves little lace.  Clear amber color.  Light carbonation and medium bodied.  Nose is malty.  Starts with sweet malts, finish is smooth with hints of hops in background.  $2.09 for a 12oz bottle from Tulleys beer & Wine Wells, Me.
Earlier Rating: 5/21/2005 Total Score: 3.3Pours with a three-finger light tan head, fades slowly and leaves a good lace.  Cloudy amber color.  Light-medium carbonation and light bodied.  Nose is raisiny/medicinal.  Starts sweet with the malts, finish is tart raisin but is too thin.  $4.95 for a 750ml bottle from Colonial Spirits Acton, Ma.  Batch #47.

12 oz bottle.  Pours slightly red brown with a small white head.  Light aromas of dark fruits, green apples, toasted malts.  Flavor is slightly tart green apples, biscuity malts, a touch of honey and a little dark fruit.  Pleasant but also somewhat weak flavor.

Dark iced tea colored pour with a ruby highlight and a large 3 finger off-white head.  Subtly toasty caramel nose with some faint grass, dark fruit and cedar.  Flavor is as equally subtle as the aroma with hints of caramel, almond, vanilla, dates, and cocoa.  Medium body with a soft carbonation and a tad watery finish.  Definitely a tasty and drinkable beer for being a high-po Belgian but it just seems to be lacking in body and flavor.
This dark amber, near brown, dubbel wears a thin tan head, and carries notes of caramel amid a woodsy earthy background.  Plenty of balanced malt, not too sweet, real smooth.  A fine dubbel.
tap at the memphis taproom- pours brown with thin offwhite head. nose is bubblegum, wheat? yeast, full bodied and very good. lots of subtleties about this one.
I’m getting lots of malt. Some cherry. Sweetness. Even a bit of chocolate. "Should I open another?" I asked the wife. "Is it a bomber?" she asked. "Yes." "Then do it." And so this was opened.

Pours a murky brown typical of the style with very little head (surprising considering the amount of pressure the Reserve is under). Aroma has some belgian funk, and definitely some candi sugar, but it is also apparent that this is not your traditional Dubbel. Very delicious with lots of chocolate and bubbliness. Finishes surprisingly dry, especially for the style. Not at all unenjoyable. Different, not what I was expecting, but awesome. I want to find another bottle of this to lay down and see how much better it is in a few years.

750 ml bottle purchased from Spirits Red Bank. Pours a super deep dark mocha brown with small bubbly carbonation clinging to the side of my Allagash glass and a super large foamy creamy super light beige head. Aroma is nice and complex with lots of yeasty goodness, dark fruit(raisin, prunes), very light alochol which is only apparent towards the middle of my glass, some brown bread and very light brown sugar. Body is light and sightly watery, the carbonation does not make itself known untill you swallow and then it comes on with average strength. The flavor is much weaker then the aroma leads one to believe. Lots of initial chocolate, followed up with some brown bread and a little bit of sourness as well. If your going for a bottle of Allagash grab the Triple, it’s a great beer and still available at a great price.

I had this as part of my pick six at my local shop. It poured a darker, almost red color, with a fluffy head. I think this beer was spot on as far as carbonation, as well as very well balanced. The flavor could have been a bit more pronounced, but overall, I thought this beer was great. Great first impression from Allagash. Cheers!
This is a nice American version of a double, although definitely not as complex as the Belgians. The flavor is a mix of prunes and figs. Hearty and filling.

12 oz bottle.  Poured clear coppery-iced tea brown with a short, creamy, well-retained cap of beige head.  The aroma picked up dry-roasted cocoa and light raisins over dry fruity yeast and a little alcohol warmth deeper down.  The flavor was well-balanced with darker fruits, chocolate, and aged caramel at the core paired with some notes of leather and a dark, spicy yeast.. just a few fusel notes on the back detracted a bit.  Medium-bodied with emphasis on a nice yeast strain.. almost a sherry feel right at the end (with the fruit and some booze).  Tasty brew!
Bottle. Pours dark brown.  Aroma of malts and dark fruit.  Some alcohol on the nose.  Flavor is typical of a dubbel, with some added roasted malt flavor.  Good mouthfeel.  Decent dubbel.

330 ml bottle. Dark brown with an orange tint. Almost no head, but a bit of lace. Aroma: rich malt, chocolate and caramel, grains, dark fruit, Rich malty flavor, dry for a dubbel, good roasted action. Belgian yeast, dark fruits. Nice balance. Touch of citrus. A very good, somewhat stout-like dubbel. Well done. Quite complex. Doesnt have that big yeasty Belgian taste, and probably not really sweet enough. Clean, slightly fruity finish.
Bottled (12 oz). Mahogony pour, tan bubbly head. Lacy. Fruity nose--cherry, alomnd, yeast. Flavor is malt, cherry, cinnamon, yeast, spice. Dry finish. Medium, soft mouthfeel.

Everything about this beer just seemed weak.  Aroma was decent with light citrus coming through.   Pour is a basic amber with an off white head.  Watery and thin feeling citrus flavor that ended with a sharp bite.

(Bottle).  Fruity aroma.  Dark red with small off white head.  Flavor is pleasant enough, with fruits and sugar, but nothing special in the Abbey Dubbel category.   There are a great many better choices
750ml bottle.  Pours a dark hazy brown.  Smells of banna, malt and faint smell of alcohol.  Flavor is sweet with a tangy finish.

12oz. Pours an unclear brown with a tiny head.  Ripened dark fruit, caramel malt, molasses, and alcohol aroma.  Flavor is a good sweetness with some unexpected sour tanginess in there.  Not bad but surprising.  Goes down smooth and dry with low carbonation.  Not too bad.

On tap @ Brick Store. Had a huge frothing white head. Poured a deep plum color. Nose of strong malts and dark fruits. Upon first taste I am impressed with the balance of sweet fruits and smooth drinkability. The menu said this was 7.5%, but the alcohol was well concealed beneath a blanket of fruit sweetness. Delicious, and I’ll certainly try it again!

Bottle sampled at NFB&WF ’08 at Martha Clara Vineyards.  Pours a hazy amber.  Very musty aroma; reminds me of a basement in an old house.  I’m wondering if this bottle has been laying around for a while.  Flavor is a bit better.  Still some mustiness, but also sweet with some brown sugar and malt.  Disappointing, but worth revisiting down the road.
Bottle @ Brewery and Draught @ Dogfish Cafe.  Very sweet with fruit flavors predominating.  Raosted malts and coffee astringengy present is backgraound.  Very drinkable and well worth seeking out.

Draught. Pours a dark brown with reddish highlights and a big, tan head. Aroma is cocoa, roasty, a bit nutty and molasses. Taste is sweet and malty, molasses and brown sugar, a bit spicy, roasty and cocoa. Finish is a bit dry. Fairly crisp carbonation, creamy and full bodied. Very unique take, delicious.
Bottle. Chocolate, coffee, dried dark fruits, roastiness, alcohol sweetness, sweet prunes. Low carbonation, but not syrupy. An unusual dubbel. Not bad.

Bottle at Milltown. Pours a dark hazy ruby with a two finger creamy light tan head. The nose is sweet, malty, lightly spicy, earthy, Belgian, and rusty. The flavor is sweet, malty, spicy, lightly warm, tastes rusty. Crisp and malty palate.

Bottle.  Pours a dark brown/amber with a small light tan head.  Aroma of roasted malts, chocolate, fruits, yeast, and peanut butter.  Flavor strongly of nuts, with some roasted malt, dark fruits, alcohol.  I had this on tap awhile ago and really enjoyed this, but having it now, out of a bottle, it was uninspiring.  Just ok for me.
12 oz bottle. Dubbel Ale. light amber color, with a long lasting small head. sweet aroma of malts and fruits. smooth tasting, sweet but not sticky. nice beer with a slightly dry finish

Ontp @ Coles Bufflo NY. Pours an light amberish brown. Sweeter aroma of toasted malts, brown sugar. Taste is somewhat fruity,sweet malty, caramel, toffee, . Body is a tad light but overall not too bad

4-Pack that recently showed up, I’ve liked what I’ve had from Allagash so far so I didn’t need any convincing to give this a try. Dark, fruity malt aroma with an earthy/grainy quality partnered with mild spices. Deep amber pour with a 1/4" foamy head and great lacing. Hearty with a complex finish that leaves this beer clean and drinkable. Solid flavors of figs, raisins, and musty yeast. Some toasted malt and toffee was also noticed along with a bit of coffee and licorice. Not overly complex for it’s style, a solid offering.

75cl bottle from Total Wine (Tampa, FL). Pours a dark cloudy brown with a thin white/tan head with minimal lacing on the glass. Aroma is sweet malt,  caramel, brown sugar, candy sugar, yeast. Flavor is roasted malt, brown sugar, some spice, yeast, bread. Medium-bodied with a smooth finish. Nice ale.
Bottle Pours out a hazy mahogany topped with a nice sand head. Aroma of yeast, some spice and a little sweetness. Tast the yeast along with some clove and a few other spices. Not bad

Poured a muddy dark brown color with a white-ish head with good retention. Smell was spicey with a bit of clove, seemed different. Light taste of brown sugar and spice, and a little clove, just seemed bland. Light bodied, high carbonation. Really light and dry on the tongue, I was looking forward to trying this, just a little let down. I may try it again sometime to see if I was missing something, but I really didn’t care for this.

UPDATED: AUG 18, 2008 12 oz. Translucent mahogany with a two-finger head that settles into a lasting ring with soapy lace. Aroma is clove, banana, and wheat bread. Flavor is similar, with some cocoa and the spicy banana on front, and the wheat bread and dry yeast on the finish. Some sourish berry thrown in for good measure. Medium body is lightly carbonated smooth and dry.

750 ml bottle.  Bach #62.  Dark leather color.  Thin, off white head.  Aroma of honey and maple syrup.  Yeasty flavor with a bready malt backbone.  Dark fruits come out to play as well.  Clean finish.

Quite drinkable, albeit not a favorite, and probably not something I would seek out again, but I am glad that I was able to try this beer.  Tastes reminiscent of a doughy cinnamon raisin swirl sweet bread.  Washed down with some fruit juice.  Liquid bread.
Bottle.  Cloudy brown pour with nice thick tan head.  Nice lacing.  Aroma of raisins, malt and chocolate.  Taste of bread, spices malt and sugar with a slightly peppery finish.

Bottle. Hazy reddish-brown. Thick light tan head. Spicy. Bread crust, lots of bakery aromas and spice with a hint of smokiness too. Tastes include bread crusts and slight anise and tamarind plus dried fruit but is not sweet. Instead is peppery and dry. Soft chewy mouthfeel, perfect for style. Very nice dry rendition.

750 ml bottle from Hollingshead Deli; Nose is corriander, cloves, and light sweetness and hoppiness;Hazy brown with a big, long-lasting, glass-lacing, beige head; flavor has light hop bitterness, spices, and caramel; finish light bitterness.

750 mL bottle. Beer pours a dark brown body with little head. The aroma has slight notes of alcohol and roastiness.  The taste is roasted malts - alcohol finish - 7%? eh..
Poured a murky brown color with a nice off white head. Aroma was very sweet and malty with a nice vineous apple smell. Flavor was a bit subdued but very smooth candy sugar and dark fruits and spices.

Bottle, Kegs & Barrels, McKinney, TX.
Poured a hazy copper with very nice beige head, excellent retention, stayed with the beer. Aroma of light citris, almost like an orange/apple.
